p: Unmanned aerial vehicles offer unique opportunities for Spatial Ecology because of their ability to almost on-demand acquire very high-resolution imagery ( Anderson and Gaston, 2013) and by using sensors tailored to the task as well as 3D structure of plants which will allow further inferences of plants physiological and structural traits at an unprecedented spatial scale ( Niphadkar and Nagendra, 2016). Remote Sensing of invasive alien plants is often difficult because these occur in disturbed areas, “mixed pixels” and under canopy ( Bradley, 2014). UAVs represent an exceptional opportunity to detect invasive plants due to their operational flexibility ( Müllerová et al., 2017a, b). This allows researchers and stakeholders to improve their mapping efforts by focusing on a particular phenological stage of the target species ( Hill et al., 2016), e.g., the peak and post peak of flowering season.
